BE11:22am

Capital frame underpinned by portfolio breadth and quality. Shell’s 22% net income beat and strong CFFO ($12.1bn v consensus at $11.bn) was overshadowed by management commentary seen to be dialing back on the target to deliver $25bn of buyback by 2020 if weak macro conditions persist. While this cautionary statement seems sensible in light of weak macro indicators across the board (oil, gas; chemicals likely to be the leading
indicator to recession risk), we believe that underlying CFFO fundamentals remain strong (JPMe CFFO exfinancials in 2020/21: $55/54bn at $65/60/bbl Brent). Taken together with capex flex to mitigate weaker oil prices (i.e. operating at the low end of $24-29bn range), this means cash breakevens ($66/bbl on 9M’19) should continue to trend lower in 2020 (JPMe $56/bbl). We view this as an important prerequisite to our view that Shell’s cash return targets remain intact especially if oil price remain under pressure. Notwithstanding a major recession we come back to our feedback published after marketing our Bullish Oil Equity thesis on the road that an overwhelmingly bearish outlook seems to be the starting point in investor’s view on oil and oil equities. With that in mind, while Shell’s outlook on a slowing global economy is clearly negative, at a 2020 dividend yield of 6.2%, 2020 cash breakeven of $56/bbl, and FCF yield of 7.5% in 2021 (on $60/bbl Brent) we believe the risk/reward is positively skewed and reiterate our OW thesis.

Soundbuy By checking here https://fever-tree.com/en_US/where-to-buy

BE11:23am

Overall, this was a strong set of results, despite a challenging environment, with robust cashflow delivery. However, the quarter was materially helped by strong trading and
optimisation results in both Integrated Gas and Downstream, which are not always
repeatable. The company has flagged that the macro conditions mean that the buyback programme for 2020 may not be fully completed, as Shell may not be able to afford the buyback, while also reducing gearing to 25%. While the intention is clear, this
announcement will create uncertainty around the deliverability of the cash return
programme to 2025, which could weigh on investor sentiment.
● Cash flow was strong at USD12.1bn in the quarter, excluding working capital movements (USD12.3bn including a working capital benefit). This is 5% ahead of the consensus for USD11.5bn of cash flow for the quarter. The strong cash flow also came after a USD0.5bn
pension payment in the quarter and a weak quarter of associate dividends, both of which would have boosted cash flow further in a “normal” quarter.
● The company has announced the next tranche of its buyback programme for USD2.75bn. However, it has highlighted that the current macro environment is weaker than the company’s financial assumptions, which could mean that Shell slows the pace of the buyback in 2020 and does not complete its full USD25bn programme within the 2020 timeframe. There will be approximately USD10bn of buybacks left to do in 2020 to hit the target.

Lloyds shares have sold off sharply ahead of today’s Q3 2019 results, down
greater than 6% in 7 trading days, perhaps reflecting a perception of increased political
risk. It now reports a loss per share of 0.5p in the quarter, primarily due to a
£1.8bn PPI “top-up” (guidance range £1.2-1.8bn). Additionally, u/l PBT of £1.8bn
is an 8% miss against company-compiled consensus, primarily reflecting
notably weak Other Income and higher impairments. The 2019 buyback is duly
cancelled. All pretty grim; we expect the shares to fall further today

BE11:34am

3Q19 Adj. PBT £1,822m, 3% below UBSe, 8% below consensus...LBG reported 3Q19 adj. PBT of £1,822m, 3% below UBSe and 8% below company-compiled consensus, driven primarily by Other Operating Income 9% below market forecast and Expected Credit Losses (ECLs) – driven by single name provisions – 15% above consensus. Net interest income was a 1% beat with NIM at 2.88%, in line with the market at 2.87%, slightly supported by an Effective Interest Rate adjustment in NII relating to MBNA customers. Guidance for a full year NIM of 2.88% and loan losses below 30bps are in line with previous targets....with capital generation strong – ex PPI – and Pillar 2A lowered slightly LBG's CET1 ratio reported at 13.5% including accrued dividends, seeing the bank delivering 149bps of underlying capital generation in 2019 to date – 28bps after the £2.45bn in YTD PPI provisions. Guidance for FY capital generation of 75bps implies a year end CET1 ratio of ~13.7% including accrued dividends, a gap of £400-600m to management's 12.5% + 100bps buffer capital target. This capital objective is retained despite a 10bps reduction in Pillar 2A requirement from the PRA to 2.6% in 3Q19, a ~£200m reduction in group capital needs

BE11:34am

Underlying business in good shape despite the softer non-interest income printLBG reiterated this year's full year NIM target, upgraded its communicated cost expectations for 2019 to sub £7.9bn – a £100m improvement – and stuck with plans to reduce the cost / income ratio in 2019, as before. We do not think either the Other Operating Income or Expected Credit Loss run rates in 3Q19 are worth annualising into 2020 – though we expect this and the NIM trajectory to be a key focus on the conference call.Valuation: 7.5x FY20e EPS, 1.1x TNAV for a 15% adj. RoTEWe have LBG trading at 7.5x 2020e earnings, 1.1x TNAV for a 15% forecast adj. RoTE, with the firm delivering an underlying RoTE of 15.7% in 9M19.

This was William Chalmers’ (CFO) first outing. A very matter-of-fact style, very clearly on top of the business / numbers (able to handle pretty much all questions of detail, while bringing it back to what matters) as you would expect from a former prominent FIG banker, somewhat reminiscent of George Culmer – and he came across as very solid CFO material. We think the market will be very comfortable with him and we look forward to some pizzaz at the FY19 results update when Antonio makes his appearance.

Irish HF guy @nightingale20201, yes. LLoyds squeezing operating costs, reduced them by 4.6% in 9m to Sep19, looks like it will generate meaningful cash next year.

BE11:36am

Further updates from 3Q19 call: Key take-aways: 1) Other Income: Expect the trends experienced in 3Q19 to prevail in the short-term given the macro backdrop but there are obvious areas to be cautious on in simply assuming the 3Q19 performance is a run rate that can be extrapolated for the purposes of projections for 4Q19 and beyond (e.g., no gilt sales in 3Q19, surely business investment will pick up a little with more political certainty next year, etc.). 2) PPI: In broad terms, the indication, in our view, is that LLOY has been mildly conservative with respect to its PPI provisioning – noting that the £1.8bn charge is what it believes is appropriate following its work but there is always an element of judgment here and it makes no sense for a new CFO to be in any way biased towards an optimistic determination; 3) Capital Generation / 4Q19 Guidance: Confirmed that the underlying capital build for FY19 will be slightly below guidance at 1H19 results stage due to PPI – hardly surprising. Note that NIM of 288bps in 3Q19 was in line with FY19 guidance (9M19: 289bps), which implies a 4Q19 exit NIM in the low to mid-280s (which should serve to rebase FY20+ NIM expectations). Improved FY19 costs guidance earlier this morning. Expect FY19 AQR

Here's Shore to summarise:

Irish HF guy LLoyds is much bigger in the UK and has £447bn lent out and £420bn of customer deposits. RBS is much smaller in the UK, UK only £150bn. Much more corporate lower margin in RBS
BE11:46am

Crest has new management and this has led to a review of operations that we still hope will lead to the generation of higher quality earnings by broadening the tenure spread and bring its homes into more of the mass market range [historically it has been a premium product and high price builder]. The new message is that the focus of the group will change but that there are bumps in the road getting there – this drive a double profit warnings and two provisions.

LK Hyman @ FATDAZ I bigged up on dull old Unilever. I'll take 3% yield over 6% plus given the risks to Big Oil. Unilever has very little risk and the company is even more "decent" than Shell.
Shinshin The BoE chatter was about whether govt would announce now so they got to make the choice rather than have possible new govt start process over with only 6 weeks to go before end Jan
GBKrona thanks @Irish
11:46 am
BE11:46am

First, there will be fewer land sales. These have tended to be high margins and fairly substantial as Crest has a long landbank but in future it will limit the sales to truly non-core and surplus assets.
Second, core operating costs are to be reduced. Whereas most other house builders have an overhead to sales ratio of 3-4% Crest’s is still 6% so there is room to do this. Part of the problem is that the group’s sales never rose to the target levels but costs did and with a new focus, there will be a lot of fat to trim.
Third, sales in the core markets have been tough through H2 (which ends today) and especially in the rump London business – this has resulted in lower margins, weaker sales and a £10m land write-down. The latter is a shock and should be a red flag for all house builders still operating in London.
Fourth, there is to be a provision of £17m driven by the Grenfell findings for the replacement of flammable cladding.
Fifth, there is concern about on-going market weakness that leads to profit warnings for the current year (FY2019) and next year. We were close to consensus with PBT estimates of £147m and £153m but we are now looking at £120-130m followed by a pre-exceptional £110-120m. The latter is a big drop given that the FY2019 figure is bearing the provisions and the underlying drop is much greater than the headline

nightingale20201 @GBK....RBS' NIM could be worse....look at HSBA at 1.5%!! amongst the big 4, Lloyds has had the edge in NIM for a number of years ...now BARC is ahead of the pack reporting at 3%...
BE11:46am

This is Robin Hardy, of course.

BE11:47am

One crumb of comfort is that the dividend of 33p is to be maintained.

The read across is there as a warning for the rest of the sector but the market is likely to want to see this as limited. Crest is largely higher end product and wholly Home Counties biased. However, the warnings signs for the wider market reason to be concerned are visible here. We have talked about the risk of earnings shocks and surprises being under-estimated in the sector and that there is too much focus on what goodies Brexit will deliver. This update shows that there is still plenty to be worried about before we get there.

Keep banking gains from the recent sector surge across the sector.

FATDAZ @LK Hyman fair enough and I fully understand .... my concerns/ interests are about a lack of choice and concentration of risk for investors going forward
11:48 am
BE11:48am

Liberum, meanwhile, withdraws its buy rating.

BE11:48am

The new CEO, Peter Truscott, has reset expectations as the new strategy takes shape. Guidance for underlying EPS for 2019E and 2020E is now 16% and 30% below our last published estimates. We believe that the new strategy will aim to reduce costs (at overhead and build level) and accelerate production by increasing the number of outlets per site. The new CEO has a good track record of margin improvement, especially at Linden. The shares should find support from the NAV, which we estimate to be around 330p and the dividend which will be maintained at 33p in 2019 and 2020, supported by a strong balance sheet and the cash generation from its new strategy.

GBKrona @nightingale20201 thanks - I guess BARC includes the Investment Bank.

Under review now.

Pru is caught in a strategic dilemma. Its main focus is on Asia, but its US
business is still a very significant part of the group. We show that: 1) 60% of group capital requirements are in the US; and 2) low US peer valuations
undermine Pru’s group valuation. Until Pru can either de-risk its US business or exit it, we think its shares will continue to underperform.

BE12:03pm

Pru is leaving its London-based Solvency II supervision
and moving to a new regulatory regime in Hong Kong, called the Local Capital Summation Method (LCSM). Pro forma, coverage is an impressive 338%. However, we think the US business’ capital requirements are understated. This is because the LCSM takes 100% of the minimum US regulatory requirements (RBC), which doesn’t reflect the higher risk of the variable annuity book. Jackson is reserving to a new standard called CTE98. This is equivalent to a 400% RBC ratio. Assuming 400% RBC instead of 100%, Pru’s group LCSM ratio would fall to 180%. On this basis, c.60% of Pru’s capital requirements are in the US, diluting the group’s appeal as an Asian growth stock, in our view.

Our media team have initiated coverage of Prosus today with an Outperform. The thesis is that the discount to NAV is too large and Tencent too cheap. With a clear preference for emerging market food delivery and a desire to reduce the discount to NAV, we think Prosus will want to show capital discipline and is unlikely to materially raise its offer. We don’t think Takeaway will raise its offer given many of its shareholders seem indifferent to the deal even as is. There’s a good chance both offers fail. On a risk-reward basis, that implies downside risk to Just Eat and we stay Underperform

BE12:11pm

There seems a strong likelihood that Prosus will lower its 90% shareholder acceptance hurdle rate in its offer but how low? The playbook at Prosus’ other food delivery assets is centred on huge investments which largely crowd out competition. Could you win a war if you have to frequently update the opposition on your fire power and progress? We think a delisting would be very desirable i.e. a 75% hurdle rate. Prosus could take 50% and build up but in a fast paced industry like food delivery, is patience an option? Knowing this, the hold-outs could demand a lot.
